thread.title: Seventh-seeded Warrensville Heights upsets No. 2 Elyria Catholic, 66-58 in OT
thread.title_full: Seventh-seeded Warrensville Heights upsets No. 2 Elyria Catholic, 66-58 in OT

author: Matt Goul, cleveland.com
title: Seventh-seeded Warrensville Heights upsets No. 2 Elyria Catholic, 66-58 in OT
text:
ELYRIA, Ohio – When Warrensville Heights played Elyria Catholic in late December, it did so without senior guard Joseph Vallery or coach Brian Swift. 
The next month was not kind to the Tigers either, but that doesn’t matter now. 
Not after Warrensville Heights’ 66-58 overtime road upset of second-seeded Elyria Catholic in their Division III sectional final. The effort advances Vallery, Swift and Co. — all present for their rematch — to the district semifinals Tuesday at Garfield Heights. 
The seventh-seeded Tigers (10-14) will play No. 3 Gilmour, a 72-49 winner against Wickliffe. 
For Vallery and his teammates, it’s a step closer to redemption. Warrensville lost by two in last year’s district semifinals to eventual state runner-up Villa Angela-St. Joseph without leading scorer Yavari Hall. This group returns to that stage after Vallery scored 24 points and fellow senior guard Sha’Mar Latham added 21 with five 3-pointers. Halftime buzzer beater for Joseph Vallery of @Warrensville_BB pic.twitter.com/4bTSVBnKMV — Matt Goul (@mgoul) March 3, 2017 
Check back later for more video highlights, reaction and Saturday's Boys Basketball Rewind. 
The Tigers have won five of their last six, including a win against Lake Erie League-rival Maple Heights — ranked 14th in the final cleveland.com Top 25 — and now No. 23 Elyria Catholic (16-7). 
“We’re just playing our ball,” Latham said. “It’s all coming together.” 
A 6-foot guard, Latham’s hot shooting helped the Tigers congeal in the final six minutes of the fourth quarter. They trailed by seven points, as Dorian Crutcher and the Panthers attacked the basket and took advantage of 17 turnovers. 
Vallery found creases in the EC defense, and Latham scored the tying 3 with 4:30 to go. The fourth quarter concluded with both teams scoring in the final 10 seconds, but Vallery’s end-to-end score with 3.6 left forced overtime. 
“We played bad the whole game,” Vallery said. “We didn’t play our top stuff. We played angry. I told them, ‘We’ve got this.’” 
Crutcher led Elyria Catholic with 21 points. Sean Szabo scored 11 and set the Panthers’ all-time 3-point record in his final game. Szabo hit three 3s Friday, and his last basket cut Warrensville’s overtime lead to one point. Donovan Warfield w/the steal and finish - plus Jarred Logan behind the back - to push @ECHSAthletics effort. pic.twitter.com/6DTwx3ddKA — Matt Goul (@mgoul) March 3, 2017 
The Tigers closed on a 9-2 run. Vallery scored 16 of his 24 in the fourth quarter and overtime. 
“He really took over in overtime,” Elyria Catholic coach Phil Kuchta said. “When you put him out there with Sha’Mar Latham and Brandon Rush , those three guards are as good as any in Northeast Ohio.” 
To Swift, Vallery’s improvement this season and junior Donte Norris ’ return from injury made this late run — Friday and for the season — possible. 
“He gives us a different look and rotation,” Swift said of Norris, who hit a fourth-quarter 3. “All of those guys fit their roles. Sha’Mar Latham has been great all season.” 
So has Rush, a sophomore guard who added 11 points and nine rebounds. He scored seven points in the second quarter as Warrensville hushed an early EC surge. The Panthers jumped out to a 10-2 lead, but Vallery served as a calming influence in huddles and talks. 
Warrensville didn’t have that Dec. 28 when it lost to Elyria Catholic, 70-56.
